title: French Impressionists in the Louvre (Art Ebook).pdf
description:
Pdf / English / H. N. Abrams / 1958 / 320 pages / 46.2 MB

IMPRESSIONISM was born from the meeting of two men with names so alike that at first they were often taken for one another: Monet and Manet. From the cross breeding of their two methods was born modern painting. It would be hard to imagine two more different people. In their social positions they were far apart. Manet was a middle class Parisian, son of a magistrate, whose horizons were the boulevards, and his earth the pavement. He never accepted the popular verdict that he was a rebel. He made up to the judges at the various Salons, and managed in the end to get hold of the Legion of Honour, at a time when his comrades in the fight were still being treated as pariahs. After the Commune, in 1870, had burnt part of Paris, Manet was held in horror as a rebel and insurgent, and all that was revolutionary in art and literature was laid at his door. The disapproval of society changed this gentlemannered person into an exasperated being
